guides.name: Python
guides.description: This is a language I highly recommend for beginners. Most language constructs are simple, many of the issues are solved either by libraries or by StackOverflow.

guides.name: C/C++
guides.description: This is a standardized language for general-purpose programming. It is a good language to learn if you are new to programming.

guides.name: Rust
guides.description: Rust is more powerful than C/C++, but it's still has a bit of a learning curve.

guides.name: Java
guides.description: The language behind Minecraft and Android Applications. Cross-platform, similar to C/C++

guides.name: JavaScript
guides.description: This is a language that is used for web development. With the introduction of NodeJS, you can write a full-stack application in JavaScript. It's a bit convoluted and missing typechecking, has some extra syntax, and is a bit of a pain to code correctly.

guides.name: TypeScript
guides.description: Solves most issues with JS, has a learning curve. Requires NodeJS and compiles to Javascript.

guides.name: VS Code
guides.description: Code Editor made by Microsoft. Requires extensions to be installed. Easily my favorite IDE.

guides.name: Git
guides.description: Git is a version control system. It's a good way to keep track of changes to your code. Must learn if you are programming.

guides.name: GitHub
guides.description: GitHub is a code hosting and sharing platform. It's a good way to share code with others, and to collaborate on projects.

guides.name: Windows Subsystem for Linux
guides.description: Some code cannot be run on Microsoft Windows as it depends on custom functionality. This is a good way to run code written for Linux on Windows.

guides.name: StackOverflow
guides.description: Probably the most helpful site for learning programming. Ask questions, and get answers; probably answer other questions as well.

guides.name: Heroku
guides.description: Want a place to run and host your code ? Heroku allows you to create 'Dynos' which are lightweight containers that run your code, used mostly as a Platform-as-a-Service.

guides.name: Railway
guides.description: `Bring your code, we'll handle the rest` - Another place to store and run code.
